position.marginalia_text: verborum: Buda[e]us ipse, philologus, et polyhistor, nec solidus Legum interpres: Hotomanus, nimis asper in Justinianu[m], et Tribonianum; nec tam de Materia sollicitus, quàm de Forma; in qua tamen ipse interdum peccat: reliqui ferè eiusdem Nota[e], omnia, et nihil: in Grammaticis, et Historicis grauissimi Censores; in ipsis Legum ponderibus, satis, superq[ue] leues: in externa superficie, curiosi; in visceribus, et medulla negligentes: certè maximè acuti, et solliciti, vbi minimè opus. Ego contrà, nec verba negligo, nec Formam pra[e]termitto; imò verba curo, et Forma[m] accurro: sed rem ipsam, et materiam, et Finem respicio, examinoq[ue] curiosissimè. Siquis reprehendat; mihi non displicet, vt placeat sibi: sit alijs venia, etiam liberis ingenijs, maiori cura in Res incumbere, quàm in verba; nec substantiam Legum, aut Glossaru[m], aut etia[m] Doctoru[m] contemnere, propter circumstantiam nullius momenti, aut minutissimi. Quos hactenùs legerim, Jurisconsultoru[m] peritissimi Logici; Vigelius, Bodinus, Freigius, Vulteius: nec despiciendi in suis Legalibus Dialecticis, Hegendorphinus, Cantiuntula, Apellus, Oldendorphius, Euerardus, Hotomanus: et Ciceronis Topica, cu[m] Tala[e]i pra[e]lectionib[us] et Omphalij Nomologia, et Talia Multa suu[m] habent opportunu[m] Vsum: sed ego ha[e]rere malim in paucorum certissimis, constantiss[im]isq[ue] principijs: vt Methodo Vulteij, Lagi, Bodini: Analyse Freigij: Praxe Vigelij: qui causaru[m] argumenta, et probationes solet syllogistico Judicio judicare. Prudentis est, eligere pra[e]gnantissima[m] Materia[m] cu[m] efficaciss[im]a Forma.

marginalia.translation: in words. Even Budé, the philologian and polymath, is not a solid interpreter of laws. Hotman is too rough with Justinian and Tribonianus, and more concerned with the content than the form, in which - in any case - he sometimes errs. In general, I have left notes of the same kind: everything and nothing. They are sharp critics in grammatical and historical things, but lighter in those weighty matters of law, curious about the surface, but negligent when it comes to the heart and marrow. Certainly, they are sharpest and most concerned when the work is at its slightest. I, on the other hand, neither neglect the words, nor overlook the form. I mine every word and examine the form. I study and consider the subject itself, and the material, and the goal, with the utmost curiosity. If anyone should find fault with me, I am not displeased by his pleasure. But I hope the kindness of other, liberated intelligences will pay greater attention to the subject than to the words, and not scorn the substance of the laws or the glossary, or even the learned men, because of a circumstance of no, or small, weight. Thus far I have read those lawyers of the most skillful logic - Vigel, Bodin, Freigius, Vulteius - and not those whose legal dialectic is awful: Hegendorphine, Cantiuntula, Apel, Oldendorp, Everaerts, and Hotman. Cicero's 'Topica', Talon's 'Praelectiones', Omphal's 'Nomologia', and many other works have their uses. But I prefer to stick with a few certain and secure foundations, such as the method of Vulteius, Lagus, and Bodin, the analysis of Freigius, and the practice of Vigel, which suffices for arguing and proving cases and judging according to syllogisms. It is wise to choose the most pregnant material, in the most effective form.
